title.title: Action
cahiers individualists de philosophie et d’art

div.p: Literary and artistic magazine associated with Individualist Anarchism, a movement based on personal freedom, social justice, and pacifism. An ultimately unsuccessful attempt to oppose André Breton’s Dada-surrealist aesthetics. Literary contributors included André Malraux, Antonin Artaud, Paul Éluard, Alfred Jarry, Erik Satie, and Tristan Tzara. Artists included Maurice de Vlaminck, Demetrios Galanis, and Robert Mortier.

title.title: La
Cité
urbanisme, architecture, art public: revue mensuelle

imprint.date: From July 1919 to August 1932. Monthly, later irregular

div.p: Leading Belgian architectural and urban design journal of the period, covering avant-garde theory and practice in Europe and America, especially the De Stijl movement. Organ of the Société belge des urbanistes et architectes modernists. Numerous photo illustrations and drawings. Artist/architect contributors included Theo van Doesburg, J.J.P. Oud, Piet Mondrian, and Henry van de Velde.

Produced by Tristan Tzara as a response to attacks on him by Francis Picabia and André Breton about the future of the Dada movement. Printed in black on pale pink stock, with typographic and pictorial collage cover. Literary contributors included Paul Éluard, Georges Ribemont-Dessaignes, and Erik Satie. Cover design attributed to Iliazd.

Foundational journal of the Dada movement. Served as an interchange for various literary and artistic avant-gardes, e.g., Futurism, expressionism, and cubism. Criticism, poetry, original artwork, and inventive graphic design. Literary contributors included Tristan Tzara, Georges Ribemont-Dessaignes, and André Breton. Artists included Jean Arp, Francis Picabia, Marcel Janco, Enrico Prampolini, Hilla de Rebay, Hans Richter, Arthur Segal, Raoul Hausmann, and Viking Eggeling.

Artistic and literary journal intended to foster communication among avant-gardists at home and on the front during World War I. Commentary, poetry, and original artwork. Literary contributors included Guillaume Apollinaire, Max Jacob, André Lhote, and Ricciotto Canudo. Artists included Amédée Ozenfant, Albert Gleizes, Sonia Lewitzka, André Favory, and Zina Ozenfant.

Important avant-garde Danish art, literary, and musical review. Contributions on aspects of the European avant-garde and modernist developments in Scandinavia, as well as African and Peruvian art. Profusely illustrated, including numerous original prints, many in color. Literary contributors included Poul Uttenreiter, Tom Kristensen, and Emil Bønnelycke. Artists included Axel Salto, Gabriele Münter, Harald Giersing, Albert Naur, Per Krohg, and Vilhelm Lundstrøm.

Art and literary magazine that promoted the Hungarian Activists and international avant-garde trends, especially constructivism and Dada. Banned by the Soviets in 1919, after which Kassák moved the journal to Vienna. The title is both the acronym of the Hungarian Activists, and the Hungarian word for “to-day.” Literary contributors included Lajos Kassák, Aladar Komjat, Matias Gyorgy, Sandor Barta, Jozsef Revai, Pal Szines, Robert Reiter, and Janos Macza. Artists included Vincenc Beneš, Janos Matis Teutsch, and László Moholy-Nagy.

Landmark Futurist literary and art periodical. Manifestos, poetry, and commentary. Briefly revived in 1920 by Mario Dessy with F.T. Marinetti’s permission. Literary contributors included F.T. Marinetti, Corado Govoni, Paolo Buzzi, Enrico Cavacchioli, W.B. Yeats, Alfred Jarry, and James Joyce. Artists included Fortunato Depero, Luigi Russolo, and Emilio Notte.

A foundational surrealist publication in which Ivan Goll and his associates laid claim to the term surrealism coined by Guillaume Apollinaire in 1917. With a manifesto, and articles on various aspects of the arts, including literature, cinema, and painting. Literary contributors included Guillaume Apollinaire, Marcel Arland, Pierre Albert-Birot, René Crevel, Joseph Delteil, Paul Dermée, Jean Painlevé, and Pierre Reverdy. Cover designed by Robert Delaunay.

title.title: The
Style
Monthly Journal of the Expressive Professions

div.p: Platform for avant-garde fine and applied arts, architecture, urban planning, music, and poetry. Associated with the De Stijl group that adhered to an austere, abstract style. Manifestos, criticism, poetry, and original artwork. Literary contributors included Theo van Doesburg and Antony Kok. Artists/architects included Piet Mondrian, Georges Vantongerloo, Bart van der Leck, Gerrit Rietveld, Hans Arp, and Sophie Taeuber-Arp.

Documented the work of the expressionist theater ensemble, Sturm-Bühne, that had premises near Herwarth Walden’s Galerie Der Sturm. Literary contributors included Herwarth Walden, Lothar Schreyer, and Rudolf Blumner. Artists included Kurt Schwitters.

title.title: Art Monthly
Magazine of the Group of Plastic Artists

div.p: Publication of a group of young Czech cubists who split off from the Mánes Association of Fine Artists, mounted shows in Prague of such leading European avant-garde artists as Pablo Picasso and Edvard Munch, and themselves exhibited at the Galerie Der Sturm in Berlin. Literary contributors included František Langer. Artists included Josef Čapek, Emil Filla, Otto Gutfreund, Vincenc Beneš, and Antonín Procházka.

title.title: Gegenstand
internationale Rundschau der Kunst der Gegenwart

div.p: Short-lived but influential journal intended to promote avant-garde Russian art in Europe. Focused mainly on suprematist and constructivist developments. Covers designed by El Lissitzky, printed in black on col-ored stock. Literary contributors included Il’ya Ehrenberg. Artists included El Lissitzky.

Publication of the Mánes Association of Fine Artists, a large, secessionist exhibition society that facilitat-ed contacts between Czech artists and the European avant-garde. For many years the premier Bohemian avant-garde periodical, with contributions on art, architecture, and literature. Literary contributors included František Xaver Šalda, Milos Jiránek, and Julius Meier Graefe. Artists included Jan Kotěra, František Bilek, Karel Vitĕzslav, and Jan Preisler.

Promoted European avant-garde art to an American audience, as did Alfred Stieglitz’s eponymous Fifth Avenue gallery. Inspired by European efforts at fusing the visual and literary arts, especially visual poetry. With essays, poetry, commentary, and original artwork. Princeton’s set is the gift of painter Georgia O’Keeffe. Literary contributors included Katharine N. Rhoades, Agnes Ernst Meyer, Max Jacob, Georges Ribemont-Dessaignes, and Guillaume Apollinaire. Artists included Francis Picabia, John Marin, Marius de Zayas, Edward Steichen, and Alfred Stieglitz.

title.title: Broom
an International Magazine of the Arts

div.p: Important Dada oriented literary and artistic periodical. Color-printed covers; tipped-in illustrations; large format. Literary contributors included Conrad Aiken,Wallace Stephens, e.e. cummings, Gertrude Stein, Virginia Woolf, Luigi Pirandello, and Louis Aragon. Artists included Pablo Picasso, Man Ray, Henri Matisse, Paul Klée, George Grosz, Wassily Kandinsky, and Amedeo Modigliani.

Bruno infused his magazine with what he called the "Bohemian atmosphere." He covered art shows, poet-ry readings, drama, and other literary events, both in his Garret and in Greenwich Village. He excerpted from London avant-garde magazines, such as The Egoist, and translated from German avant-garde works, such as Der Sturm. Illustrated with black-and-white linecuts; small format. Contributors included Djuna Barnes, Alfred Kreymborg, Marianne Moore, Vincent Starrett, and Ford Madox Hueffer.

Short-lived but ambitious, East & West sought to redress the journalistic and pictorial tendencies con-spicuous in the magazine world, with verse used for the most part as a stopgap and comparatively little fiction save from the pens of writers already known (George Sidney Hellman [ed.], 1927). Essays, fiction, verse, comments, dramatic criticism, reviews. Artful typography. Princeton owns issues in original condition complete with advertisements and wrappers. Many issues given by the editor, G.S. Hellman, with his inscription.

Publisher Edmond Bailly oriented the journal as he was inclined: toward a certain “intellectual anarchism” and “philosophical and esoteric speculation.” Printed on red and other colored papers. Contributors included the editors as well as Jules Laforgue (posthumously), A.-F. Herold, E. Dujardin, Pierre Quillard, André Gide, Stéphane Mallarmé, and Remy de Gourmont.

Financed by book publishers Albert and Charles Boni, The Glebe led as a locus for experimental writing. William Carlos Williams was first published in The Glebe. The editor was part of an artists’ colony called Grantwood, located near Ridgefield, NJ, which included Man Ray, Marianne Moore, and Mina Loy. Contributors included Ezra Pound, James Joyce, Richard Aldington, as well as Russian author Leonid Andreyev, and the German writer Frank Wedekind.

title.title: The
Mask
A Quarterly Illustrated Journal of the Art of Theatre

imprint.date: Quarterly. Suspended publication during World War I.

div.p: Theater director and designer, actor, and wood-engraver, Craig began this journal in Florence after work-ing in London and Berlin. Like his lover, Isadora Duncan, he had a “passionate conviction for a unified theatre experience of dance, music, colour, and staging, which crossed national boundaries” (ODNB.) Editorial notes, book reviews, notes on art and theater from England, Russia, Germany, Holland, France, Belgium, Italy, and the United States. Large format, woodcut illustrations, letterpress. Issued in both a popular edition and in deluxe with prints signed by Craig. Contributing writers and artists included Rupert Brooke, Isadora Duncan, Hugo von Hofmannsthal, Jean-Jacques Olivier, and Ellen Terry (Craig’s mother).
Published the new poetry and verse dramas of Rupert Brooke, John Drinkwater, Wilfrid Wilson Gibson, and Lascelles Abercrombie. Included the first publication of Rupert Brooke’s poem “The Soldier.”

Nord-Sud sought to encompass regions of the avant-garde, such as cubists and surrealists, like its name-sake, the firm which built the Métro line linking Montparnasse and Montmartre. In addition to the editor, authors contributing included Guillaume Apollinaire, Louis Aragon, André Breton, Max Jacob, Philippe Soupault, Paul Dermée, Tristan Tzara, and Justin Frantz Simon.

God knows that America in the past decade, flooded with huge selling stereotyped magazines aiming to please everybody just a little and the droves of pushing business grubbers a great deal, needed hosts of little honest journals to bring to light now and then something disturbing or beautiful. Hervey White deserves a preposterous amount of thanks for running such a magazine at a financial loss … (Gorham B. Munson, 1921). Contributors included Harold Ward (poetry, criticism), William Murrell (art criticism), and Carl Lindin (translations from the Swedish). Artists contributing: drawings, wood-cuts and linoleum-cuts by William Schumacher, Jean Paul Slusser, and Fernand Léger.

The editor’s circular announcing Secession declared it an organ for the youngest generation of American writers who are moving away from the main body of intelligent writing in the United States since 1910. They are defining a new position from which to assault the last decade and assault the next. Another edi-tor described it as our Dadaist experiments … our exegesis of the Machine Age. The publication also included French authors admired by the Youngest Generation.n In addition to the editors, contributors included Louis Aragon, Hans Arp, Slater Brown, Robert Coates, Malcolm Cowley, Hart Crane, e.e. cummings, Waldo Frank, Marianne Moore, Philippe Soupault, Wallace Stevens, Jean Toomer, Tristan Tzara, Glenway Wescott, John Brooks Wheelwright, and William Carlos Williams.

SIC stands for Sons, Idées, Couleurs, Formes. The journal was a champion of Futurism and later, cubism. In May 1917 it declared Futurism is not a school; it is a movement, a persuasion. It is the spirit of the advanced. It is the inexhaustible love of the new. Special issues focused on seminal events such as the premiere of Guillaume Apollinaire's play Mamelles de Tiresias, subtitled drame sur-réaliste. Artists contributing included Giacomo Balla, Fortunato Depero, Enrico Prampolini, and Gino Severini. Writers contributing included Guillaume Apollinaire, Pierre Albert-Birot, Louis Aragon, Gino Cantarelli, Jean Cocteau, Paul Dermee, Pierre Drieu La Rochelle, Raymond Radiguet, Gino Severini, Philippe Soupault, and Tristan Tzara. Music by Albert-Birot, Francesco Pratella, and Igor Stravinsky.

According to one of the editors, it was founded to forward D.H. Lawrence's doctrine for a revolutionary society. The editors were the sole contributors to the journal. Katherine Mansfield published under the pseudonym of Matilda Berry.

This magazine is a moral matter, not a bibliophilic one. It does not include works of entertainment, nor drawings, poems, short stories, or observations for the sole purpose of explanation or education. Accepted for publication are only those challenging European attitudes (Ludwig Rubiner, 1917). Poems and prose together with signed art. Illustrated by artists associated with German expressionism. Line-cuts, both full page and partial. Writers included Thomas Mann, Rainer Maria Rilke, Hugo von Hofmannsthal, and Martin Buber. Music by Arnold Schoenberg. Artists included Paul Klee, Oscar Kokoschka, and George Mathey (teacher of American artist Lynn Ward).

title.title: La
Chronique musicale
Revue bi-mensuelle de l'art ancien et modern

div.p: Published after the 1871 French defeat in the Franco-Prussian War, this journal reflects new currents in French thought focusing more on French music and its history and less on German (particularly prevailing Wagnerism). Such preference for the national was regarded as advanced. Critic Arthur Pougin re-ferred to La chronique musicale as a superb journal, which was a model of its genre, a review published at a literary and artistic level until then unknown in the world, and as an extremely useful publication in which excellent taste prevailed. Contributors were among the most well-known and the most knowledgeable [French] writers on music of the period, including the prominent librettist Charles Nuitter, composer and archivist Théodore de Lajarte, and historian and critic Adolphe Jullien.

From the start, this journal tried to move from under the oppressive weight of German/Austrian music and advocated performance by developing Czech composers, gradually focusing more and more on the national character of Czech music. Became a leading journal of the Czech modern movement in the 1920s. Illustrations, portraits, music. Issued in three series: 1858-69; 1873–75; and 1878-1927.

The most distinguished German arts journal of the Jugendstil period, Pan is celebrated for its typographic design and original graphic art. Founded by Otto Julius Bierbaum and Julius Meier-Graefe, Pan highlighted international developments in art, literature, theater, and music.

title.title: Ver sacrum
Organ der Vereinigung Bildener Künstler Österreichs

div.p: Ver sacrum, or Sacred Spring, was the official publication of the Vienna Secession. The title references an ancient religious rite, and speaks to the regenerative power of youth in exile. The Secessionists had come together in 1897 to oppose the Austrian art establishment and pursue a freer, experimental art. The journal is replete with original prints by Gustav Klimt (1862-1918), Koloman Moser (1868-1918), Josef Hoffmann (1870-1956), and others.

Founded by polymath Herwarth Walden (1879-1941), Der Sturm was the principal mouthpiece of German Expressionism. In addition to this journal, Walden promoted the international avant-garde through a Berlin gallery, theater, lecture agency, and publishing house—all of which carried the Der Sturm moniker.

interpGrp.desc: Links identified names in this document with the VIAF name authority.
